I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  With Viet Nam’s accession to the World Trade Organization and the country’s further 
integration into the world economy, the Government recognizes that raising the industrial and 
banking sectors’ efficiency to an internationally competitive level will be foremost among the 
challenges it faces. It has, therefore, reaffirmed that state-owned enterprise (SOE) reform, 
particularly phased government divestment in nonsensitive SOEs, is a key component of its 
overall  strategy,  and  the  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan 1  emphasizes  the  need  to 
accelerate change to achieve these objectives. 
 
2.  The Government requested Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) help  to formulate an 
assistance  modality  to  further  accelerate  SOE  reforms  and  enhance  overall  corporate 
governance. The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) will prepare the SOE Reform 
and Corporate Governance Facility (SRCGF). The TA is included in the country strategy and 
program (CSP) update, 2006–2008, while the proposed SRCGF is included in the CSP, 2007–
2010, for Viet Nam. The CSP reflects ADB’s support for SOE reform as a means of continuing 
the country's path toward economic growth and poverty reduction (the initial poverty and social 
analysis is in Appendix 2).2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The SOE sector (which includes state-owned commercial banks [SOCBs]) is critical to 
continued economic growth. SOEs account for over a third of gross domestic product (GDP) 
and roughly half of exports. SOEs also contribute about 70% of tax revenue (as value-added 
and corporate income taxes). Yet, they pose a number of major challenges. SOE debt, a large 
portion  of  which  is  nonperforming,  has  been  estimated  at  about  one  half  of  GDP.  SOE 
performance  has  been  impeded  as  many  enterprises  face  rising  inventories,  low  financial 
reserves, and high debt levels. One half of SOEs are either loss making or marginally profitable. 
 
4.  SOE reform efforts began in earnest in the late 1990s and accelerated in 2000 with the 
adoption  of  a  comprehensive  5-year  SOE  reform  plan,  which  sets  annual  targets  for 
transforming  SOEs.  SOE  restructuring  options  include  equitization,  conversion  to  a  single-
member limited liability company, merger, sale, lease liquidation, or bankruptcy. (As over 90% 
of SOE transformations are via equitization, it has received the most attention within and outside 
the Government.) SOEs that are deemed to be of key strategic value or that operate in areas of 
national interest must remain 100% state-owned. Improvements in corporate governance have 
been modest. The Government officially reaffirmed its commitment in 2005 to equitize about 
50% of remaining SOEs within the next 3 years. The New Enterprise Law of 2005 provides that 
all remaining SOEs must be corporatized by 2010.  
 
5.  SOE reform is a multi-step process that includes transformation, equitization, and listing. 
Equitization is the transformation of an enterprise into a joint stock company that operates under 
the Enterprise Law applicable to private enterprises. Equitization has been streamlined through 
the revised legal framework, and a number of incremental policy initiatives support the listing of 
equitized  enterprises.  However,  accomplishments  have  fallen  short  of  targets,  and  most 
equitizations have been carried out in small and medium-sized enterprises. The more difficult

6.  In 2003, the Government created the Debt Asset Trading Corporation (DATC) within the 
Ministry of Finance to, among other things, help SOEs restructure their debt before equitization. 
Although set up by the Government as a centralized asset management company, DATC is 
hampered by the lack of enabling powers and regulations to carry out its mandate. It does not 
possess the skills and capacity to resolve distressed assets. Efforts will be needed to strengthen 
the newly established State Capital Investment Corporation (SCIC) to manage state equity in 
firms and invest state-owned assets assigned by the Government. SCIC began operations in 
August 2006 and, as of September 2006, was representing Government ownership in 70 SOEs. 
The Government eventually plans to run SCIC based on Singapore’s Temasek model. A social 
safety fund was established in 2005 to compensate, and fund training of, employees rendered 
redundant by restructuring. 
 
7.  The net result is that only about 14% of state capital had been transferred to the private 
sector by the end of 2005, with a large proportion of shareholders being existing employees. 
Corporate governance standards have improved modestly at best. Based on the sector study 
completed in 2005 the major barriers against SOE reform are outlined below.4  
 
A.  Equitization  and  Listing  of  State-Owned  Commercial  Banks  and  General 
Corporation Groups Slowed by Limited Financial Resources 
 
8.  The SOE sector study noted that the transformation and eventual equitization of SOCBs 
and GCs will be costly and difficult. Without the necessary support, reform of the largest GCs

and SOCBs is expected to be considerably delayed. A simplified summary of the steps for a GC 
or SOCB to transform, equitize, and list in the stock exchange is in Appendix 5. 
 
9.  State-Owned Commercial Banks. Organizational and financial restructuring of SOCBs 
has proven difficult and occurs immediately before equitization. A major difficulty facing all 
SOCBs  is  resolution  and/or  restructuring  of  their  nonperforming  loans,  which  lowers  their 
operational efficiency and capital adequacy ratios. Asset classifications and income recognition 
in the banking industry are based on the Vietnamese Accounting Standards, which tend to 
result  in  underreporting  of  NPLs.  Subscribing  to  the  International  Accounting  Standards  is 
expected to lead to recognition of a higher level of NPLs. Solving the problem of high NPLs 
through  financial  restructuring  before  equitization  will  therefore  require  significant  capital 
infusion. Although no SOCB has yet been equitized or listed, the Government plans to equitize 
Vietcombank and Mekong Housing Bank (MHB) during the fourth quarter of 2006 or early 2007. 
Vietnam Industrial & Commercial Bank (Incombank), Bank of Investment & Development of 
Vietnam (BIDV), and Vietnam Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (VBARD) will be 
financially  restructured  and  equitized  later.  The  SOE  sector  study  identified  the  need  for 
significant long-term financial support to SOCBs that are slated for equitization to amortize the 
costs of restructuring and equitization over longer periods. Such long-term financing would 
increase their competitiveness, strengthen their post-equitization financial structure, indirectly 
recapitalize SOCBs, and increase their long-term viability, which has become more relevant in 
the wake of Viet Nam’s accession to the World Trade Organization.   
 
10.  General Corporations. All member SOEs within a GC cluster (footnote 3) must be 
transformed, usually by equitization, before the apex GC is equitized. This means that the 
transformation of the most difficult SOE in the cluster will delay the whole process for all SOEs 
in the cluster, including the apex GC. It also means that the largest entities (where the potential 
benefits of corporatization are the greatest) will have the greatest difficulties. Debt or liability 
restructuring is estimated at about 90% of the equitization cost for GCs. GCs will be unable to 
amortize these costs over a suitable period because access to long-term financing is limited, 
reducing  their  competitiveness  and  hindering  equitization.  Indeed,  no  large  GC  has  yet 
completed the process even though some started 2 years ago. Of the 124 GCs that have 
announced their intention to be converted into holding companies and to be equitized, 52 have 
had their transformation proposals approved but only 8 have reached the third stage, able to 
operate under the new model. No GC has yet both equitized and listed its shares on the stock 
exchange. 
  
B.  Institutional Support Needed for DATC and SCIC 
 
11.  Estimates put total SOE debt at about half of GDP, with about $1.8 billion classified as 
nonperforming. The legal mechanisms to resolve nonperforming loans need to be carefully 
reviewed, and enforcement of foreclosure provisions improved, with more clarity, particularly on 
land-use rights. State-directed lending has exacerbated the problem and caused difficulties for 
SOCBs.  
 
12.  Equitization should be viewed as only the first step in the long transformation of an SOE 
into a globally competitive enterprise. For example, while Viet Nam has equitized more than 
3,000 companies, only 53 are listed.

4   
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The  TA’s  main  objective  is  to  prepare  the  SRCGF  by  formulating  a  focused  and 
sequenced series of measures to facilitate SOE reform and enhance corporate governance. 
The measures will be consistent with and supplementary to the Government’s overall strategy 
for SOE reform. Recognizing that SOE reform is a long process and will not be advanced by 
stand-alone projects, the TA will follow a sector-based and multi-tranche lending modality for the 
ensuing loan project, covering the Socio-Economic Development Plan period (2007–2010). In 
consultation with the Government and other stakeholders, the TA outputs will include detailed 
design of the SRCGF into two components:  
 
1.  Component I: Design Assistance for Equitization  
and Listing of SOCBs/GCs  
14.  The TA will develop a modality for providing financial and technical support to select 
SOCBs/GCs for equitization and listing, with a clear set of selection criteria and guidelines for 
project implementation. The financing scheme will be used for the direct costs of equitization 
and listing, including asset restructuring (SOCBs) and debt/liability restructuring (GCs). The 
SOCBs will need to classify bad debts and make provisions according to international standards, 
and  then  assess  the  extent  of  additional  capital  required  to  meet  the  prescribed  capital 
adequacy standards. Similarly, GCs will have to resolve troublesome debts before equitization. 
In consultation with the Government, the TA will assess and identify GCs and SOCBs for 
participation under the SRCGF requiring the above assistance, including the amount. 
 
15.  The TA will clearly identify the technical inputs needed by the selected SOCBs and GCs 
to undertake activities that are considered direct costs and not funded by the Government, such 
as (i) financial restructuring, (ii) valuation for equitization, and (iii) listing in the formal stock 
exchange.  This  component  entails  financial  support  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources 
under the SRCGF. 
 
2.  Component II: Design an Institutional Development Scheme  
for SOE Reform 
 
16.  The TA will identify a set of specific measures to support the institutional development of 
DATC and SCIC to ensure their long-term sustainability and effectiveness, including various 
institutional  and  human  resource  development  components.  The  TA  will  examine  and 
recommend legal and policy reforms to improve these institutions and promote SOE reforms. 
The TA will further examine and recommend measures for reforming organizational structures 
to improve corporate governance and operational efficiency in the selected GCs and SOCBs. 
Funding  from  ADB’s  Asian  Development  Fund  window  under  the  SRCGF  is  envisaged  to 
implement these measures. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
17.  The design of the SRCGF’s components will initially be based on the recent SOE sector 
study and feedback given to ADB by the Government and its agencies. Participatory workshops 
will be organized to build consensus on the outputs.  The TA will be implemented in two phases, 
commencing in March 2007. Phase 1 will cover all the activities as stated in paras. 14–16, and 
include the detailed design for the SRCGF, including procedures, strategies, and operational

5
plans for each component; the institutional capacity development plan; a draft development 
policy matrix; and implementation arrangements. To ease the transition to implementation, 
$175,000 from the TA will be used separately on an agreed plan at the end of the final design 
and start of the SRCGF under phase 2. The allocation of consultant resources for phase 2 will 
be decided by ADB in consultation with Government under a separate contract, preferably with 
the consulting firm engaged under phase 1 subject to satisfactory performance in the initial 
assignment. 
 
C.   Cost and Financing  
 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost a total $1,000,000 equivalent, of which ADB will provide 
$800,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from the Technical Assistance Special Fund 
($300,000)  and  the  Financial  Sector  Development  Partnership  Fund  ($500,000)  and 
administered by ADB. The Government will provide the remaining $200,000 equivalent by 
providing counterpart staff and other support facilities. The cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 3. The Government has been advised that approval of the TA does not commit 
ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  will  be  the  Executing  Agency,  while  its  Enterprise 
Department  (for  GCs),  the  State  Bank  of  Viet  Nam  (SBV,  for  SOCBs),  and  the  (National 
Steering  Committee  for  Enterprise  Reform  and  Development  (NSCERD,  for  overall  policy 
development) will be the implementing agencies. In addition to stakeholder reviews, a steering 
committee  will  provide  guidance.  It  will  be  chaired  by  the  vice  minister  of  finance  or  his 
representative, and comprise the Enterprise Department, SBV, the State Securities Commission, 
NSCERD, and the line ministries of GCs that have been selected for support under the SRCGF. 
Tripartite  review  meetings  involving  the  steering  committee,  consultants,  and  ADB  will  be 
chaired by MOF. 
 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 17 months, from early March 2007 to July 2008. The 
TA implementation will be contracted out to an international consulting firm for 16.0 person-
months for international and 16.5 person-months for national consulting services to carry out 
phase 1. (The allocation of resources for phase 2 will be decided at the end of the final design 
and start of the SRCGF under a separate contract [para. 17].) The fixed-budget selection 
method is proposed to select the consultants. Short-listed firms will submit technical proposals 
with detailed terms of reference. All the consultants will be selected in accordance with ADB's 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2006, as amended from time to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund, and (ii) ADB 
providing  the  balance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $300,000  on  a  grant  basis,  to  the 
Government of Viet Nam for preparing the State-Owned Enterprise Reform and Corporate 
Governance Facilitation Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Viet Nam: 
 
SOEs remain a crucial part of the economy and are an important source of employment for the poor. The TA is 
expected to formulate a project that will help increase SOEs’ contribution to economic growth, job creation, and 
poverty reduction. This will be achieved through the project, which will facilitate SOE reform, particularly equitization, 
and listing the SOEs on the formal stock market, which will make them more efficient and competitive. In the medium 
to long term, the TA and the ensuing project are expected to significantly increase jobs and reduce poverty. The TA 
will ensure that project formulation and implementation follow the Government’s goal to foster participation and 
promote social inclusion and gender-responsiveness in reducing poverty.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
The Government’s Socio-Economic Development Plan and other documents stress reducing poverty through strong 
economic growth. ADB has been active in formulating strategy through various initiatives, and emphasizes regional 
economic integration, market-based development initiatives, human resource development, and sustainable social 
and environmental management. In line with the priorities set forth in the strategy, the TA aims to address some of the 
major financial impediments to SOE reform.  
 
The establishment of transparent, market-friendly, socially inclusive, and gender-responsive business practices is 
likely to promote private sector confidence and help establish pro-poor governance structures. The TA’s impacts on 
economic growth and job creation are assessed as significantly positive. No adverse impact requiring mitigating 
measures was identified.  
 
C.  Participation Process

stakeholder consultations.

12  Appendix 4 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) implementation will be in two phases: (i) the design phase 
for  the  State-Owned  Enterprise  Reform  and  Corporate  Governance  Facilitation  Project 
(SRCGF);  and  (ii)  the  initial  implementation  phase  of  the  SRCGF,  after  its  approval  and 
effectiveness. The following terms of reference covers all activities proposed under (i) above. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  State-Owned Enterprise Reform and Corporate Governance Specialist and 
Team Leader (international, 5 person-months) 
 
2.  The international state-owned enterprise (SOE) reform specialist and team leader will 
have a successful track record in corporate restructuring of large SOEs and privatization of 
financial institutions in a number of transitional economies.  He or she will have solid technical 
expertise in SOE reform policies, especially privatization policies. As the team leader, the 
specialist will have strong interpersonal and communication skills and be a proficient writer. He 
or she will be responsible for all activities under the TA and timely delivery of all outputs and 
ensure that the team actively coordinates with the Vietnamese counterparts. Previous work 
experience in Viet Nam is desirable.  
 
3.  More specifically the specialist will do the following: 
 
(i)  Update the recently completed sector study to include latest policy developments 
and progress in SOE reform.  
(ii)  Identify  and  short-list  select  state-owned  commercial  banks  (SOCBs)  and 
general corporations (GCs) requiring financing under the SRCGF to undertake 
the equitization and listing process.  
(iii)  With  the  help  of  the  corporate  as  well  as  the  bank  restructuring  specialist, 
conduct an overall assessment of the selected GCs and SOCBs, including their 
equitization  plans,  legal  mandates,  board  and  management,  financial  status, 
business plans for the next 5 years to determine the required financial and 
technical support for their equitization and eventual listing in the stock market. 
(iv)  Develop a modality for providing market-based financial and technical support to 
equitize the selected GCs and SOCBs under the SRCGF, with a clear set of 
selection criteria, including their economic, financial, environment, and social 
dimensions. The financing scheme to be designed is to be used for direct costs 
related to equitization, including debt and asset restructuring. 
(v)  Identify the technical inputs for the selected GCs and SOCBs, covering tasks 
leading to equitization, such as (a) undertaking valuation for equitization, (b) 
defining overall business strategy, and (c) reforming organizational structures to 
improve corporate governance and operational efficiency. 
(vi)  Recommend  a  specific  set  of  measures  to  introduce  and  implement  solid 
corporate governance standards.  
(vii)  In coordination with the corporate as well as the bank restructuring specialist, 
explore possibilities to use risk management and credit enhancement tools of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help mobilize long-term resources from other 
funding channels for the selected GCs and SOCBs. 
(viii)  Design a time-bound action for the selected GCs and SOCBs to be listed on the 
stock exchange.

Appendix 4  13 
(ix)  Define methodologies for project monitoring and achievement of objectives for 
the SRCGF.  
(x)  In coordination with the rest of the team, identify a set of specific measures to 
support the institutional development of Debt Asset Trading Corporation (DATC) 
and  State  Capital  Investment  Corporation  (SCIC)  to  ensure  their  long-term 
sustainability  and  effectiveness,  and  include  various  institutional  and  human 
resource development components. 
(xi)  In coordination with the international and national legal experts, identify the legal 
and policy reform agenda to improve the functioning of these institutions.  
(xii)  In coordination with the national poverty/social sector expert, identify potential 
social risks associated with the project and prepare mitigation plans or other 
measures. 
(xiii)  Identify and propose other policy actions considered critical for accelerating SOE 
reforms. 
(xiv)  Hold workshops and other meetings with various stakeholders to ensure effective 
dissemination and consensus-building.  
 
2.  Corporate Restructuring and Financial Specialist  
  (international, 3 person-months) 
 
4.  The  specialist  will  have  extensive  working  knowledge  of  GC  restructuring.  The 
specialist’s tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  Assess and monitor the progress in the equitization of large selected SOEs (the 
GCs) and identify the impediments to and constraints on this process.  
(ii)  In coordination with the SOE reform specialist/team leader, identify select GCs 
that could be considered for support under the SRCGF. 
(iii)  Conduct  an  overall  assessment  of  the  selected  GCs,  including  their  legal 
mandates, board and management, financial status, and business plans for the 
next 5 years to determine the required financial and technical support for their 
equitization and eventual listing on the stock market. 
(iv)  Develop approaches, methods, techniques, and timing of the equitization and 
assessment of the selected GCs, including (a) a review of equitization options 
and  procedures,  (b)  valuation,  (c)  preparation  of  master  plans,  (d) company 
reorganization, and (e) redefining of strategic directions. 
(v)  Assess the extent of financial support required to be considered for support 
under the SRCGF, particularly resolving troublesome debts with long-term loans 
to enhance operational viability and efficiency. 
(vi)  In coordination with the team leader, develop a modality for providing market-
based financial and technical support to the GCs under the SRCGF, with a clear 
set of selection criteria. The financing scheme to be designed is to be used for 
direct costs related to equitization, including debt restructuring.  
(vii)  Define areas that could be considered for support under component 2 of the 
SRCGF,  such  as  improving  organization,  management,  responsibility,  and 
transparency, and enhancing corporate governance standards. 
(viii)  In  coordination  with  the  team  leader,  explore  possibilities  to  use  ADB’s  risk 
management and credit enhancement tools to help mobilize long-term resources 
from other funding channels for the selected GCs.

14  Appendix 4 
3.  Bank Restructuring and Equitization Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
5.  The  consultant  will  have  an  extensive  background  in  bank  restructuring,  asset 
disposition, and equitization. The specialist will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assess  and  monitor  the  progress  in  equitization  of  SOCBs  and  provide 
recommendations and advice for preparatory steps to accelerate restructuring 
and equitization. 
(ii)  In coordination with the team leader, identify SOCBs that could be considered for 
support under the SRCGF. 
(iii)  Develop approaches, methods, techniques, and timing of the equitization and 
assessment  of  SOCBs,  including  (a)  a  review  of  equitization  options  and 
procedures,  (b)  valuation,  (c)  preparation  of  master  plans,  (d)  company 
reorganization, and (e) redefining of strategic directions. 
(iv)  Develop an integrated and comprehensive approach to bank restructuring, based 
on the need to classify bad debts and make provisions according to international 
standards, and then determine how much more capital is required to meet capital 
adequacy standards.  
(v)  In coordination with the team leader, develop a modality for providing market-
based  financial  and  technical  support  for  equitizing  SOCBs.  The  financing 
scheme to be designed is to be used for direct costs related to equitization, 
including debt and asset restructuring based on activity carried out in (iv). 
(vi)  In  coordination  with  the  team  leader,  conduct  an  overall  assessment  of  the 
selected SOCBs to determine the required financial and technical support for 
their equitization and eventual listing on the stock market. 
(vii)  Recommend measures that could be considered for support under component 2 
of  the  SRCGF  to  strengthen  the  selected  SOCBs’  credit  policies,  risk 
management,  and  credit  approval  processes;  accelerate  implementation  of 
disclosure  and  transparency  requirements;  and  strengthen  asset  disposition 
strategies. 
(viii)  Define  operational  standards  and  implementation  performance  to  sustain 
operational efficiency during the SRCGF. 
(ix)  In coordination with the SOE reform specialist/team leader, explore possibilities 
to use ADB’s risk management and credit enhancement tools to help mobilize 
long-term resources from other funding channels for the selected SOCBs. 
(x)  In coordination with the other team members, identify a set of specific measures 
to support the institutional development of DATC and SCIC to ensure their long-
term sustainability and effectiveness, including various legal, institutional, and 
human resource development components. 
 
4.  Asset Management Company Expert (2.5 person-months) 
 
6.  The  consultant  must  have  extensive  experience  in  the  operations  of  the  asset 
management or reconstruction companies. The specialist will undertake the following tasks in 
coordination with other team members, particularly with the team leader and the legal experts: 
  
(i)  Identify the policy and legal impediments to DATC carrying out its mandate as a 
debt resolution company (acquiring and resolving nonperforming loans and debt 
assets owned by SOEs, dealing with and resolving interests received from SOEs 
upon  equitization  transaction,  and  providing  consulting  services  to  SOEs  for 
resolving nonperforming loans owned by such as SOEs).

Appendix 4  15 
(ii)  Build on the studies carried out on the assessment of the legal environment in 
Viet  Nam  for  the  operations  to  be  conducted  by  DATC,  and  examine  the 
progress on and impediments to its implementation. 
(iii)  Suggest and propose changes to existing legislation to stimulate centralized debt 
resolution. 
(iv)  Recommend incentives to accelerate debt resolution and asset disposals.  
(v)  Recommend ways to develop a secondary market for acquired assets. 
(vi)  Identify a set of specific measures to support the institutional development of 
DATC  and  SCIC  to  ensure  their  long-term  sustainability  and  effectiveness, 
including various institutional and human resource development components. 
(vii)  Identify the required legal and policy reform agenda to improve the functioning of 
these institutions. 
(viii)  Review  the  organizational  plan  of  SCIC  and  identify  capacity  and  training 
requirements  for  dealing  with  corporate  governance  issues  in  SOEs  and 
managing state capital by SCIC in equitized SOEs. 
(ix)  Identify other areas of assistance for the institutional strengthening of DATC and 
SCIC.  
  
5.  Legal  and Tax Expert (2.5 person-months)  
 
7.  The consultant will have broad experience in dealing with legal issues on SOE reforms 
and privatization as well on operations of asset management companies. Knowledge of Viet 
Nam’s legal and tax system will be an advantage. The consultants will undertake the following 
tasks in coordination with the rest of the team: 
 
(i)  Review the legal and regulatory impediments in SOE reforms and equitization. 
(ii)  Recommend legal and regulatory measures to accelerate SOE reforms. 
(iii)  Identify the policy and legal impediments to DATC carrying out its mandate as a 
debt resolution company in coordination with the asset management company 
expert. 
(iv)  Identify  the  required  legal  and  policy  reform  agenda  to  improve  effective 
functioning of DATC and SCIC.  
(v)  On  the  basis  of  best practice,  recommend  an  incentive  structure for  DATC, 
keeping in view the present tax regime. 
(vi)  Consider indemnification clauses to protect legitimate authority in the normal 
discharge of DATC duties in disposing of bank nonperforming assets. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
1.  SOE Reform and Equitization Advisor (5 person-months) 
 
8.  The national SOE reform advisor will have a background in SOE development, be 
familiar with recent developments in SOE reforms in Viet Nam, including the Government policy 
and incentives for SOE reforms and equitization. The expert should possess a comprehensive 
understanding and knowledge of private sector development in Viet Nam, and be proficient in 
English.  The  specialist  will  be  responsible  for  providing  inputs  related  to  the  frameworks, 
especially in legal and policy reform areas. The specialist will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist the team leader in all aspects of his or her tasks within the terms of 
reference.

16  Appendix 4 
(ii)  Under the guidance of the team leader, collect and analyze information, and 
make it available in English in an organized, readable form. Help the international 
team make available to the Government all report and TA outputs in Vietnamese. 
(iii)  Conduct research on specific topics as required by the team leader. 
(iv)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and help the team leader 
prepare materials for them, including translations of documents and interpretation 
of the discussions. 
 
2.  Corporate Financial Specialist (3 person-months) and Banking Specialist (3 
person-months) 
 
9.  Both will have a background in finance, understand the SOE sector, the local banking 
and capital markets in Viet Nam in general, and be proficient in English. The consultants will be 
responsible for providing inputs related to the project component of the loan. The consultants 
will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Assist the international experts in all aspects of their tasks within the terms of 
reference. 
(ii)  Under the guidance of the international experts, collect and analyze information 
and  make  it  available  in  English  in  an  organized,  readable  form.  Help  the 
international team make available to the Government all reports and TA outputs 
in Vietnamese.  
(iii)  Conduct research on specific topics as required by the international consulting 
team. 
(iv)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and help the international 
team  prepare  materials  for  them,  including  translations  of  documents  and 
interpretations of the discussions. 
 
3.   Legal and Tax Expert (2.5 person-months) 
 
10.  The expert should have a sound background of the legal and tax system in Viet Nam, 
particularly issues connected with SOE reforms, and be proficient in English. The consultant will 
do the following: 
 
(i)  Assist the international legal and tax expert in all aspects of their tasks within the 
terms of reference. 
(ii)  Under the guidance of the international legal and tax expert, collect and analyze 
information and make it available in English in an organized, readable form. Help 
the international team make available to the Government all reports and TA 
outputs in Vietnamese.  
 
4.  Poverty and Social Development Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
11.  The national poverty and social development expert should have a sound background in 
local labor laws and international labor standards, particularly SOE reform issues, and be 
proficient in English. The consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Identify how the project relates to priorities identified in the national poverty 
reduction strategy (or other national development plan), ADB’s country poverty 
analysis, and sectors identified as priorities in ADB’s country partnership strategy.

Appendix 4  17 
(ii)  Identify potential social risks associated with the project and prepare mitigation 
plans or other measures during implementation. 
(iii)  Propose measures to ensure that the project complies with national labor laws 
(e.g.,  minimum  wage,  equal  pay,  safe  working  conditions,  social  security 
contributions)  and  international  core  labor  standards  (including  freedom  of 
association, nondiscrimination and equal pay, and prohibitions of forced and child 
labor). Help the team leader identify opportunities within the project to mitigate 
the  effects  of  potential  layoffs  of  workers  related  to  government  or  industry 
restructuring or retrenchment. 
(iv)  Identify possible targets and indicators related to labor issues to be included in 
the design and monitoring framework and the project performance management 
system. 
(v)  Help the team leader resolve labor-related problems and issues, identifying labor 
law or policy changes, and drafting assurances related to labor issues. 
(vi)  Collect and analyze information and make it available in English in an organized, 
readable form. Help the international team make available to the Government all 
reports and TA outputs in Vietnamese.  
 
C.  Workshops and/or Seminars 
 
12.  The consultants will be responsible for organizing a series of workshops and/or seminars 
to disseminate the results of their work and further SOE reform. The workshop target audience 
will be decided with the Government and will include policy makers, representatives from target 
SOEs, GCs, SOCBs, and other stakeholders.  
 
D.  Reporting Requirements 
 
13.  The team leader will prepare (i) an inception report including a time-bound work program 
and revised personnel schedule within 3 weeks after services start, (ii) an interim report within 2 
months and a second interim report within 3 months after services start, and (iii) a draft final 
report within the fifth month after services start. A final report will be produced within 2 weeks of 
the tripartite meeting to review the draft final report, and incorporate comments from ADB and 
the Implementing Agency. This final report will have the design and modality of the SRGCF 
together with full details as described in the terms of reference above. Six copies each of the 
inception, interim, draft final, and final reports will be presented to the State Bank of Viet Nam 
and three copies to ADB. The team leader will submit monthly progress reports to ADB. The 
other experts will coordinate and help the team leader conduct the workshops and prepare and 
submit the reports. The reporting requirements under phase 2 will be decided at the start of the 
SRCGF.
